summary: Email correspondence between Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney Bobbi Sternheim and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding concerns about Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn. The attorney requests Maxwell be moved to an interior cell due to planned utility shutdowns, while the prosecutor relays the MDC's assessment that her current cell is appropriate and that conditions are being monitored.

events.title: Defense Request to Move Maxwell Due to Utility Shutdown
events.description: Defense attorney Bobbi Sternheim emails the U.S. Attorney's office requesting Maxwell be moved from her isolation cell to an interior cell due to a planned shutdown of water and heat at MDC from 9:00 pm to 5:00 am from November 16 to November 21, 2020.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was housed in an isolation cell with two exterior walls at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn as of November 2020.
The NYC Department of Design & Construction planned to shut off water and heat to the MDC overnight from November 16 to November 21, 2020, prompting defense concerns.
The MDC's assessment, conveyed by the prosecution, was that Maxwell's current cell was the 'most appropriate placement' for her safety and the security of the institution.
A previous court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan on August 25, 2020, had denied Maxwell's request for relief regarding her conditions of confinement.
Maxwell was permitted, by a separate court order, to review discovery materials in a dayroom cell from 7:00 am to 8:00 pm.
